intro: Lupinus latifolius subsp. latifolius, commonly known as the broadleaf lupine, is a perennial legume native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is characterized by its tall, erect growth habit and clusters of blue to purple pea-shaped flowers. The plant has palmately compound leaves with 5–9 oval-shaped leaflets, and its root system includes nitrogen-fixing nodules. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry slopes and open woodlands. This species is valued for its ecological role in soil enrichment and as a forage plant for livestock.
